column5: TITLE
column12: ABSTRACT

column4: Bawa I.G.A.G.; Bawa-Putra A.A.; Santi S.R.; Sukadana I.M.; Suryanadi O.; Indyan G.
column5: Formulation of the bark extract of Michelia champaca to control Curvularia leaf spot in rice (Oryza sativa L.)
column12: The formulation of a botanical fungicide with the active ingredient of Michelia champaca bark extract to control the growth of Curvularia verruculosa, which causes leaf spot disease in rice plants in the greenhouse was investigated. The results showed that the formula for M. champaca bark extract at a concentration of 1.5% (w/v) was reduced the disease intensity of Curvularia leaf spot by up to 66.01% at 24 days after application. This formula was also able to increase the number of tillers and leaf chlorophyll levels by 40.05% and 41.18%, respectively at 63 days after planting. The formula of M. champaca bark extract at a concentration of 1.5% (w/v) increased the yield of harvested dry grain by 89.26%. © 2024 Association of Agricultural Technology in Southeast Asia. All rights reserved.

column5: HOW TO DEVELOP A SAFE PROCESS WITH HAZARDOUS CHEMISTRY
column12: The demand for active substances for pharmaceutical and agrochemical applications is constantly increasing. Many chemical structures used in innovative active ingredients may be successfully synthesized using hazardous chemistry. Although such reactions require process safety methodology, trained employees, specialized equipment, and precautions during development and manufacturing, they can have significant advantages in terms of the number of synthesis steps, impurity formation, operating costs, and environmental impact. To develop safe and robust commercial production processes using hazardous chemistry it is crucial to assess and manage the risks and hazards from project start. In this article, we will speak about highly energetic azide chemistry in the development of a commercial scale process to manufacture a tetrazole bearing API. We will focus on managing the risks evaluation and controls to develop safe and efficient processes on commercial scale. The description is based on a real-life example of a tetrazole formation involved in a commercial API – Oteseconazole/VT-1161. © 2024 TeknoScienze. All rights reserved.

column5: ESSENTIAL OILS A GREEN FUNGICIDES FOR CONTROLLING POSTHARVEST DISEASES ON BANANA FRUITS: A REVIEW
column7: Analele Universitatii din Oradea, Fascicula Biologie
column12: Essential oils (EOs) are widely acceptable in cooking, medical, and food industrial products, because its low residual, low toxicity on humans, animals and plants. EOs are more attractive as antifungal at low concentrations against major plant pathogens than synthetic chemical fungicides for management postharvest diseases incidence on banana fruits during storage, transportation and marketing i.e., crown rot, anthracnose, neck rot and finger end rot. In vitro, EOs of cinnammon, clove, lemongrass, thyme, black seed, basil, tea tree and other oils at (1.0%) were effective for inhibition growth of fungal pathogens causing postharvest rots on banana fruit of various fungal genera such as Fusarium species, Colletotrichum species, Lasiodiplodia theobromae and Aspergillus tamarii. Different application methods of EOs can be used for controlling postharvest diseases incidence of banana fruits, such as fumigation, spray, dusting and soaking, with the high efficacy of soaking banana fruits in the essential oil suspensions by the rate (2–5%) for 10 minutes. The most antifungal mechanisms of (EOs) on fungi causing postharvest are inhibition synthetic of cell wall, increasing permeability of plasma membranes, morphological changes in cell originals, deterioration of cytoplasm contents, disrupt cell structure and death the cell. In addition, inhibition development mycelium, conidia production and conidial germination and also, inhibition formation of appressoria during invasion process as well as, inhibition the activities cell wall degrading enzymes of cellulose and pectineases during fungal infection of plant tissue. Furthermore, the synergistic antifungal effect of EOs with edible agents or modified atmosphere such as, EOs of lemongrass or citral in combined treatments with sodium carbonate, cinnamon oil or clove EOs in combination with modified atmosphere, cinnamon oil in combination with Arabic gum by the rate (0.4%–10%) respectively and the combination of clove oil and agar agar by the rate (2% - 0.02%). Moreover, application of nanoemulsions of tea tree oil in combination with sodium alginate, were highly effective for suppressive postharvest diseases on banana fruits, increasing shelf life of banana fruits and maintenance marketable characters. The future investigation the development EOs and their effective chemical components in encapsulation of micro- and nano formulations for increasing their efficacy for a long time, by slow release to loss degradation and evaporation after application. So, this review aims to focusing of applicable of EOs and their biological active components as well as development its in formulations as eco-friendly green fungicides for management postharvest fungal diseases on banana fruits. © (2024), (Analele Universitatii din Oradea). All rights reserved.

column4: Dwivedi S.; S. Yadav P.K.; Singh G.
column5: Maleic Anhydride-Based Surfactants and Their Properties
column7: Sustainability in Chemical Processes through Digitalization and Green Chemistry Approaches
column12: A novel class of surfactants derived from maleic anhydride has incredible properties. Maleic anhydride is an acid anhydride of maleic acid that is a colorless organic compound that is mostly used as an additive in the paint and coating industries. These surfactants provide excellent solubilization, dispersion, low foaming, and synergic properties. In addition, maleic anhydride-based surfactants are less toxic, biodegradable and can be produced from green synthesis. These surfactants are produced by reacting maleic anhydride with triglycerides in the presence of acid catalysts, which impart certain enhanced characteristics to the surfactant. These properties can be further demonstrated with the help of NMR, IR and elemental analysis. Additionally, maleic anhydride-based surfactants are widely used in the manufacturing of laundry detergents, hard surface cleaners, fabric softeners, cement setters, unsaturated polyester resins, coatings, pharmaceuticals and pesticides. The present paper addresses the routes of synthesis, properties and applications of maleic anhydride-based surfactants.

column4: Farhadi Z.; Ziaee M.; Esfandiari M.; Salimi A.; Rasekh A.
column5: Does microemulsification improve the insecticidal activity of cypermethrin against the melon aphid, Aphis gossypii (Hemiptera: Aphididae)?
column12: The melon aphid, Aphis gossypii Glover (Hemiptera: Aphididae) is one of the important ornamental plant pests in urban regions. In this study, the microemulsion system was developed using cypermethrin insecticide as the active ingredient, xylene as the solvent, and surfactants including Tensiofix 8427 + SDS, and Tensiofix 8427 + SLS, and 1-butanol (cosurfactant), as stabilizer. The optimal microemulsion formulation was determined using a pseudo-ternary phase diagram using the water titration method. The microemulsions mean droplet sizes were in the range 11.2–22.8 nm. The droplets of all three formulations were spherical and uniformly dispersed in water. The mortality percentage was 66.66, 56.66, and 55.00% 24 h after aphids exposure to C1-250 (cypermethrin: Tensiofix 8427 + SDS + 1-butanol: water, at the ratio of 10:20:70), C2-250 (cypermethrin: Tensiofix 8427 + SLS + 1-butanol: water, at the ratio of 10:20:70), and C3-250 (cypermethrin: Tensiofix 8427 + SLS + 1-butanol: water, at the ratio of 15:30:55), which increased to 92.86, 89.29, and 83.94%, 48 h after exposure, respectively. The results revealed that the microemulsion formulation containing cypermethrin 250 g/L was more effective in controlling A. gossypii than cypermethrin technical material and 150 g/L cypermethrin-based microemulsion. © 2024, Tarbiat Modares University. All rights reserved.

column4: Adetuyi B.O.; Olajide P.A.; Adetunji C.O.
column5: Techniques Involved in the Structural Elucidation and Characterization of Active Constituents That Could Serve as Repellent Products Containing Plant- Based Ingredients as Nanobioinsecticide
column7: Handbook of Agricultural Biotechnology: Volume IV Nanoinsecticides
column12: Farming contamination is a consequence of contemporary farming techniques. Due to the current agricultural outputs, such practice may lead to the annihilation of ecosystems, soil, as well as the surroundings. Agricultural production is somewhat harmed by the extensive usage of chemical fertilizers, insecticides, and tainted water sources. As a result, the food and agricultural industry’s present condition is no longer viable. There is a good chance that agro-based nanotechnology will significantly affect plant development and environmentally friendly agricultural production. Recent studies have demonstrated how nanotechnology has the ability to boost the effectiveness of agricultural inputs and offer answers to farming practices to increase food production efficiency and safety. The potential use of nanosized agricultural chemicals in agribusinesses, such as nanopesticides, nanosensors, and nanoformulations, has changed conventional agricultural practices and made them highly effective and durable. Nevertheless, the use of emerging nano-products in actual real-world settings prompts questions regarding the security of nanostructures, their degree of exposure, and their hazardous environmental consequences and public health. The current analysis provides information on latest events in agricultural chemicals derived from nanotechnology which have completely changed the agricultural sector. © 2024 Scrivener Publishing LLC.

column4: Soudani N.; Boukhalfa H.H.; Toumi K.; Soudani A.
column5: Human Health and Environmental Risk Perceptions Related to Pesticide Use in Algerian Market Gardening
column12: A random survey was performed in Ain Naga and Doucen of Biskra (Southeast Algeria) during 2016/2017 and 2017/2018 crop seasons to assess the environmental and human health risks posed by pesticides applied in Algerian market gardening systems, and to identify products with lower risks. Therefore, the Quebec Pesticide Risk Indicator "IRPeQ" is used to compute risk indices of 24 different active substances widely used and potentially hazardous. Data for these calculations of the Human Risk Index (HRI) and Environmental Risk Index (ERI) values are sourced from global databases of pesticides' properties. Data reveal that the Human Risk Index, formulations based on triadimntol exhibited the highest value (HRI = 4580), while formulations of Acarol 10 WP® and Hexizox® based on Hexythiazox displayed the lowest value (HRI = 20). Regarding the Environmental Risk Index, formulations containing tefluthrin and fenbutatin oxide registered the highest value (ERI = 462), whereas Maneb (a.s.) had the lowest value (ERI = 33). Mopistop® and Score® formulations are therefore identified as the most favourable products, ensuring both safe and sustainable production. © 2024, University of Zagreb - Faculty of Agriculture. All rights reserved.

column4: Anil B.C.; Savita; Shubhan; Mahrach Y.; Vidhate D.A.; Babu M.S.
column5: Application of Nanotechnology in Agricultural Systems: Improving Efficiency and Sustainability
column7: International Journal of Intelligent Systems and Applications in Engineering
column12: Nanotechnology is the field that studies how to manipulate matter on an atomic scale. The discipline of managing the smallest particles possible has the possibility of enhancing agricultural productivity in the face of obstacles that cannot be handled using conventional approaches. Improving the fertility of the soil by releasing stored nutrients is a primary goal of management, and nano clays and zeolites are used to improve fertilizer efficiency. Using nano biosensors and a satellite network, farmers can calculate the precise inputs their crops need and have them delivered to them at the perfect time and place. The development and research of nanoherbicides are being driven by the difficulties of controlling perennial weeds and decreasing the supply of weed seeds. Mechanisms such as targeted distribution, slow/controlled release mechanisms, and conditional release might allow the active components of a nanostructured formulation to be released with more precision in response to environmental signals and biological demands. Nanofertilizers have been demonstrated to improve nutrient usage efficiency, reduce soil toxicity, and buffer against the potentially disastrous effects of overdose, all while reducing the number of times they need to be applied. As a result, nanotechnology has a lot of potential for helping developing countries adopt sustainable agricultural methods. © 2024, Ismail Saritas. All rights reserved.

column4: Lina E.C.; Holeng H.S.F.; Nelly N.; Reflin; Ernis G.
column5: Nanoemulsion of the Mixture of Citronella Grass Distillation Waste and Piper aduncum Essential Oil to Control Spodoptera frugiperda (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae)
column12: Corn production in Indonesia is challenged by the attack of the new invasive pest fall armyworm (Spodoptera frugiperda, Lepidoptera: Noctuidae). This pest is known to be resistant to many synthetic insecticides. Botanical insecticide with nanoemulsion formulation is an option to solve this problem because it was relatively eco-friendly, and the various active components delay insect resistance and insect resurgence. The objectives of this research are to determine the characteristics of the nanoemulsion of the mixture of spiked pepper (Piper aduncum) and citronella grass distillate waste (Cymbopogon nardus) and to test the insecticidal activity of nanoemulsion against Spodoptora frugiperda. The nanoemulsion formulation is made with the spontaneous emulsification method. The leaf dipping technique is applied at the nanoemulsion toxicity test on S. frugiperda larvae. Then, the nanoemulsion formulation is analyzed with PSA and Zetasizer Nano Malyern to measure the particle size and zeta potential. The result of the research shows that the nanoemulsion of the mixture of citronella grass waste and P. aduncum fruit oil has insecticide activity with LC50 = 0.53%. Additionally, it causes mortality and developmental delay in S. frugiperda larvae. The nanoemulsion particle is 273.1 nm. It has homogeneity and an even distribution. © 2023, Department of Science and Technology. All rights reserved.

column4: Falcão E.L.; Barreto C.B.; da Silva F.S.B.
column5: From phenolics to proteins of Anadenanthera Colubrina (Veil.) Brenan: Potential of mycorrhizal technology to enhance the production of relevant agents to combat infectious Diseases
column7: Endophytic and Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi and their Role in Sustainable Agriculture
column12: It is remarkable the need to develop therapeutic options for the treatment of infections and several allopathic drugs are available for this purpose. However, owing to the increasing number of emerging infectious diseases and high demand for active ingredients that reduce the growth of drug-resistant microorganisms, the search for new herbal medicines should be highlighted. However, not all plant species have the potential to incorporate such formulations, making it essential to select plants that can be used to combat different types of infectious agents. In this context, Anadenanthera colubrina (Vell.) Brenan (cebil) is a Fabaceae that occurs in South America and used in folk medicine. It contains bioactive compounds from primary and secondary metabolism, which confer relevant properties in the treatment of infectious diseases. Its bark is the most used part to obtain these benefits and the one with the largest number of studies on pharmacological properties, followed by the leaves and, to a lesser extent, its fruits and seeds. Among the primary compounds, the carbohydrates present in its gum have fungicidal and anti-diarrheal actions; in the leaves, the presence of protease inhibitors was evaluated concerning their anti-inflammatory effect. Besides these biomolecules, A. colubrina produces high concentrations of phenolic compounds found in all plant organs and related to the anti-inflammatory, bactericidal, fungicidal, and anti-biofilm activities of the extract, especially proanthocyanidins and hyperosides. Apart from the seeds, which do not present sufficient studies to prove their antioxidant potential, the other parts of the cebil have in vitro antioxidant activity verified and related to phenolics, especially the proanthocyanidins. Another relevant trait of A. colubrina extracts is attributed to the low cytotoxicity, which may favor the use of A. colubrina in pharmaceutical formulations. As a means of enhancing the quality of the phytomass offered, the mycorrhizal technology, which consists of the use of selected arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF), has the potential to enhance the concentration of metabolites of pharmaceutical interest, due to the high mycotrophy of the species. Thus, this chapter will discuss the main segments that can use compounds of A. colubrina as agents that promote the treatment of infectious diseases; furthermore, it will discuss the potential of AMF in improving the quality of raw material of this species offered to the industry of herbal medicines. © 2023 Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

column4: Iddar A.; Mzibri M.E.; Assifaoui A.
column5: Recent advances in pesticides formulations and their relationship to efficacy and toxicity
column7: Pesticide Residues: Chemistry, Toxicology and Environmental Impact
column12: During the last century, crop yields have increased dramatically to cover the demographic growth of the world's population. Pesticides play an important role in agricultural production to reduce the gap between demand and supply of food, due to weeds, diseases and pest's damages in agricultural fields causing socio-economic losses. In 2018, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) estimated that globally, about 4 million tons of pesticides were used in agriculture around the world. Generally, the pure chemical pesticide and active ingredients are not used alone for pest control because of their chemical instability, low miscibility with water or even the difficulty of their application in the raw state. For these reasons, it is of great interest to incorporate pesticides into a formulation, which may contain carrier substances, adjuvants, stabilizers and other chemicals to protect active substances and improve pesticides activities. These formulations exist in various states: liquids, fine powders, emulsions, baits, gels, granules and aerosols. For final application, these formulations can be diluted in a solvent according to the manufacturer's instructions. Depending on the method of application and climate conditions, some farmers apply pesticides in more than the recommended dosage to counteract their loss due to their degradation, photolysis, evaporation and surface runoff. Therefore, some pesticide residues can remain in soil, water and agricultural products and consequently can have a negative impact on the environment and human health. Since the appearance of pesticides, researchers and manufacturers have tried to improve their formulations to limit losses in the environment and to improve effectiveness, safety, application and storage. This chapter summarizes the evolution of formulations including the new generation of pesticide formulations, called "eco-friendly formulations". The relationship between formulations, efficacy and toxicity will be developed and discussed too. The chapter is organized into 9 sections. Section 1 (introduction) describes the history of pesticides. Section 2 discusses pesticides used in agriculture and their impact on environment and human health. Section 3 informs about the basic concept of pesticides formulation. Section 4 describes the conventional formulations used in farming practices and the relationship efficacy/toxicity of pesticides and formulations (section 5). Section 6 relates the recent trends in pesticides formulations followed by the efficacy of these new generations of formulations and their fate in the environment (section 7). Section 8 discusses the challenges with the use of the "eco-friendly" pesticide formulations used in agriculture and we finish with the section 9 to give the conclusion and outlook. © 2023 Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

column4: Silva A.S.; Barbosa L.P.; Sendón R.
column5: Releasing Active Food Packaging: Can Natural Extracts be a Safety Concern?
column7: Conference Proceedings - 23rd IAPRI World Conference on Packaging, IAPRI Bangkok 2022
column12: Active food packaging has originated a revolution in the packaging world, allowing a positive interaction with food. Since this concept appeared, it has already suffered progresses and nowadays releasing active packaging tends to be more sustainable and associate with natural additives and biopolymers. In this paper, the advancements of releasing active packaging intended for food purposes will be addressed. Examples of releasing active systems developed using plants extracts (e.g. thyme, rosemary, tea) and industrial fruits’ by-products will be presented. Factors affecting the biological activity of natural extracts will be focused but also their potential contamination by plant toxins, mycotoxins, heavy metals or pesticides residues in order to draw conclusions about their safety and need of standardization. The release of active compounds from active food packaging to foods or food simulants and their effects in the oxidation status of packaged foods will be discussed. © Conference Proceedings - 23rd IAPRI World Conference on Packaging, IAPRI Bangkok 2022. All rights reserved.

column4: Santos A.L.D.S.; Rai M.; Santos F.P.D.S.; Nascimento A.S.; da Silva G.T.O.; Lima L.K.F.; Dias L.M.F.; de Oliveira Y.S.; Ayala A.P.; de Sousa S.A.A.; Feitosa C.M.
column5: Chemical characterization and larvicidal properties of the essential oils of against Aedes aegypti (Diptera: Culicidae)
column12: The mosqui to of the genus Aedes i s the arthropod responsible for transmission of the dengue virus. Some procedures are proposed to prevent the proliferation of this vector, including the use of larvicides and insecticides. The present work has as the extraction of essential oils from the species Syzygium aromaticum and Ocimun grantissimun and the evaluation of their active components against Aedes aegypti larvae. The oils were subjected to GC-MS analysis to identify the majoritarys compounds. The EOs were subjected to turbidimetric tests to obtain the degree of solubility in 1% DMSO, acetone, alcohol and Tween 80. The analysis of EOs by GC–MS resulted in the identification of eugenol, 1-8-ci neol e and β-caryophyl l ene. Test s wi t h t he enzyme acetylcholinesterase were performed following the protocol of Ellman adapted by Rhee. The turbidity of the EOs in ethanol presented values from 30 to 102 NTU, implying the presence of a greater number of sol ubl e mol ecul es. Studi es of l arvi ci dal assays of S. aromaticum and O. gratissimun oils showed LC50 values of 39.5 and 54.6 mg/ml respectively. For anticholinesterase activity, O. gratissimun presented an IC50 of 6.2 mg/ml . The present work suggests the essential oils under study are promising in the formulation of larvicides and insecticides. © 2022 Revista Brasileira de Plantas Medicinais.

column5: The fungicidal activity of phenothiazine and some of its oxidation derivatives
column12: Phenothiazine, used at the rate of 2 lb. to 50 gal. of water, with or without adjuvants, is of value as an orchard spray against apple scab. Laboratory studies show that it is also toxic to conidia of Sclerotinia fructicola and apple bitter-rot organisms. Laboratory studies of the oxidation derivatives, phenothiazine-sulphoxide, phenothiazone, and thionol, indicate that the active principle of phenothiazine is phenothiazone, and that phenothiazone is toxic in dilutions as low as 2.5 p.p.m. by volume of water. Limited phytocidal studies show that the material may be safely applied to pear, apple, plum, cherry, grape, rose, lilac, and bean foliage. Peach foliage is slightly injured by the treatments.

column5: SUMMARY OF TOXICOLOGICAL INFORMATION ON 2,4-D AND 2,4,5-T TYPE HERBICIDES AND AN EVALUATION OF THE HAZARDS TO LIVESTOCK ASSOCIATED WITH THEIR USE
column12: The acute oral ID50 values for 2,4-D; 2,4,5-T and their various derivatives commonly used as herbicides fall in the range of 300 to 1,000 mg/kg for mice, rats, guinea pigs, rabbits and cattle. Dogs are generally more susceptible and chicks are more tolerant of this type of material. The acute oral ID50 values for commercial formulations of 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T that were used in these experiments were proportional to their content of active ingredient. The "inert ingredients" do not appear to contribute materially to the oral toxicity of the formulations. MCP (2_methyl_4_chlorophenoxyacetic acid) and silvex (2-(2,4,5_trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid) and their herbicidal derivatives appear to be slightly less toxic than the corresponding 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T materials. The hazard to livestock and wildlife associated with the use as recommended of herbicides containing 2,4-D, 2,4,5-T, MCP, and silvex is negligible. Toxic amounts of these materials can be obtained if animals have access to spray tanks or other containers.

column5: CONTROL OF COFFEE BERRY DISEASE IN KENYA
column12: Coffee Berry Disease causes serious crop losses in Kenya. The pathogen may be active throughout the crop cycle, that is, for a period of 8 to 9 months, from flowering to ripening. East of the Rift Valley there tends to be a steady loss over this period, whereas in the west Rift and in some Mount Kenya districts the main epidemics occur during June-October. The degree of infection of berries is directly related to their position on the branch, the permanent reservoir of inoculum being the external tissues of the twigs. The effect of copper treatment at critical periods is to reduce the potential inoculum production of the branch tissues to a point below the numerical threshold necessary for infection. In districts east of the Rift there is only one critical period for control (February-April) but in the West Rift a second period of spraying (June-October) is advisable. The critical spraying periods are related primarily to periods of maximum growth, the wave of infection which moves to the freshly maturing stem tissues being retarded. Comparative fungicide trials using twenty-five formulations of different active principles have shown that copper is the most effective.

column5: TOXICITY OF METHYLURACIL + SUBSTITUTED UREA + PHENOL COMPOUNDS TO SHEEP
column7: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN VETERINARY MEDICAL ASSOCIATION
column12: As many as 11 daily oral doses of 6 different chemical formulations, representing 3 general categories (methyluracil and substituted urea and phenol) were given to sheep. Calculation of each dose was based on a milligram per kilogram of body weight of the active ingredient contained in commercial products. Five herbicides were given at the rate of 250 mg/kg. Following this, all compounds were given at lower dose rates to determine the relative toxicity of each formulation. Of the herbicides studied, 2 compounds, a liquid formulation of alkanolamine salts of dinitro-o-sec-butyl phenol and a wettable powder product with linuron (3[3,4-dichlorophenyl]-l-methoxy-1-methylurea) as the active ingredient, produced the most severe toxicosis to sheep. Use of these compounds in areas where sheep might be grazing should be avoided, especially where application to pastures equals or exceeds 1 qt. or 2 lb. of the active ingredient per acre, an approximate concentration of 25 mg/sq ft. In contrast, diuron (3[3,4-dichlorophenyl]-l, 1-dimethylurea) at 25 mg/kg appeared to have little toxic effect when compared with other substituted urea compounds as measured by weight changes in the sheep during the trial period.

column5: MOLLUSCICIDAL PROPERTIES AND SELECTIVE TOXICITY OF SURFACE-ACTIVE AGENTS
column7: BULLETIN OF THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION
column12: Of over 100 commercially produced surface-active agents tested against the bilharziasis vector snail Biomphalaria sudanica, 13 were found to possess considerable and highly selective molluscicidal properties at concentrations of less than 1 ppm for exposures of 48 hrs. Against Crustacea, fish, water plants, mosquito larvae, mice, and the eggs of B. sudanica, the toxicities of the 13 surfactants were slight. The chemicals did not appear to be absorbed by organic matter to any appreciable extent. It is thought that the toxicity to B. sudanica is of both a chemical and a physical nature.

column5: TRANSLOCATION OF 12 FUNGICIDAL COMPOUNDS INJECTED INTO TREES OF PRUNUS DOMESTICA
column12: A cycloheximide derivative, five 8-quinolinol compounds, one pyridinethione, one organic mercury, one organophosphate, a phenyl sydnone, four Phytoactin formulations, and an alcohol were branch injected at various concentrations into Italian prune trees. Translocation characteristics were determined by quantity absorbed, distribution of high-concentration injury symptoms, and bioassay of stem tissues from selected locations in treated trees. The results indicated that all compounds were translocated to some extent, and the performance of 8-quinolinol benzoate was outstanding. This compound was distributed throughout the tested parts of trees treated with 5000 ppm, and bioassays were successful for as long as 407 days after treatment. Structural differences among the 8-quinolinols accounted for slight differences in translocation and for prominent differences in bioassay results. The presence of methyl alcohol with 8-quinolinol benzoate accounted for similar differences for that compound. The severity of symptoms caused by the Phytoactin preparations varied inversely with the percentage of active ingredient contained in the undiluted product. This indicates that the observed phytotoxicity was not caused by the antibiotic. Bioassays of root, fruit, and leaf tissues were made from trees treated with cycloheximide thiosemicarbazone. Positive results were obtained only with leaf extracts.

column4: KRISHNAIAH, K; TANDON, PL; MATHUR, AC; MOHAN, NJ
column5: EVALUATION OF INSECTICIDES FOR CONTROL OF MAJOR INSECT PESTS OF OKRA
column12: Field trials were laid out in the summer and rainy seasons of 1972-1974 to evaluate 26 insecticides for the control of major insect pests of okra (Abelmoschus esculentus Moench.). Carbofuran seed treatment at 5% protected the crop from attacks of the leaf-hopper (Amrasca biguttula biguttula Ishida) and shoot-borer (Earias vittella Fab.) until the initiation of fruit set. The efficacy of seed treatment was not affected even when the treated seed was stored for 2 mo. The protection offered by soil application of granular formulation (at sowing) from jassids was fensulfothion and phorate (1.5 kg ai[active ingredient]/ha) for 7 wk; disulfoton (0.5 kg ai/ha) for 6 wk; carbofuran (1 kg ai/ha) and mephosfolan (1.5 kg ai/ha) for 5 wk. Monocrotophos, dimethoate (0.3 kg ai/ha) and endosulfan (0.7 kg ai/ha) suppressed jassid populations effectively for 3 wk. Other promising insecticides for jassid control were carbaryl (2 kg ai/ha), acephate, vamidothion, chlorfenvinphos, leptophos, demeton-methyl, dicrotophos and phosphamidon. Aphids (Aphis gossypii Gl.) were kept in check by monocrotophos, dimethoate, methomyl, acephate, chlorpyriphos, vamidothion, naled and fenthion. Weekly sprays were necessary for the control of fruit-borer damage. Monocrotophos, methomyl (0.5 kg/ha), endosulfan (0.7 kg/ha) and carbaryl (0.75 kg/ha) gave effective control of borers infesting the fruits. Chlorpyriphos, chlorfenvinphos, tetrachlorvinphos, phoxim, Dipel and pyrethrins were promising in reducing fruit-borer damage.

column5: EFFECT OF BENLATE AND OTHER SYSTEMIC FUNGICIDES ON MYCELIAL GROWTH AND SCLEROTIA PRODUCTION OF TYPHULA-INCARNATA LASCH EX FR
column12: On PDA [potato dextrose agar], benlate (Du Pont Benomyl) at 50 ppm a.i. [active ingredient] virtually prevented any sclerotia production of T. incarnata, the snow mold pathogen of winter barley. A combination of methylthiophanate and the inert ingredients of benlate displayed the same effect. Neither methylthiophanate nor the inert ingredients of benlate alone were able to suppress sclerotia production completely. Apparently, a pure MCB methyl benzimidazol-2-yl-carbamate fungicide and one of the inert ingredients of benlate exert a synergistic influence on sclerotia production and mycelial growth of the fungus.

column5: EFFICACY OF NEMATICIDES FOR CONTROL OF MELOIDOGYNE-JAVANICA IN GROUNDBED AND CONTAINER PRODUCTION OF MARANTA
column12: Soil drench applications of carbofuran 4F and oxamyl 2L at 22.4 kg a.i.[active ingredient]/ha to ground beds of native Florida [USA] sand plus peat planted to M. leuconeura kerchoveana, and infested with M. javanica, suppressed nematode levels and galling of squash seeded in treated soil 1 mo. after treatment. Applications to similar plants grown in pots on raised benches showed that drenches of carbofuran at 0.06 kg a.i./100 l, ethoprop 6EC at 0.04 kg a.i./100 l or oxamyl at 0.03 kg a.i./100 l were more effective than granular formulations at 22.4 kg a.i./ha 1 mo. after treatment. Roots of okra growing in soil treated with ethoprop, oxamyl or aldicarb 10G at 11.2 kg a.i./ha exhibited practically no galling. Significant galling occurred in soils treated with carbofuran or in soil obtained from Maranta which had received 4 foliar sprays of oxamyl at 0.12 kg a.i./100 l applied at 3 wk intervals. At 4 mo. after treatment, okra roots were free of visible galls only for the ethoprop drench and yielded low populations of M. javanica larvae. Carbofuran drenches produced necrotic flecking and marginal necrosis of Maranta foliage.

column4: SOMOGYI, A; MALICK, LE; LANGENBACH, R; SALLACH, K
column5: CONTEMPORARY ANIMAL NUTRITION AND ITS POTENTIAL HAZARDS TO HUMAN HEALTH
column7: ZENTRALBLATT FUR BAKTERIOLOGIE MIKROBIOLOGIE UND HYGIENE SERIE B-UMWELTHYGIENE KRANKENHAUSHYGIENE ARBEITSHYGIENE PRAVENTIVE MEDIZIN
column12: The growing challenge to secure wholesome food of animal origin in quantities sufficient to feed the ever increasing world population leads to the need to search for new means to enhance animal production. Such an endeavor often involves the use of pharmacologically active agents. As new substances are continuously introduced into agriculture, the necessity clearly arises to reassess the requirements for the approval of compounds likely to appear in the food of man via edible tissues of animals. Since a number of animal drugs and feed additives show carcinogenic potency, problems encountered while planning animal studies for the safety evaluation of chemicals were discussed. Among the most important factors to be considered is the test substance metabolism. Most carcinogens require metabolic transformation in order to react with macromolecules and, thus, exert their biological action. Residues of many drugs in animal tissues appear to be various metabolites rather than the parent compounds themselves. At present, it is not known whether many chemical residues are simply stored in different compartments of the carcass as a result of their physico-chemical properties or whether they are covalently bound to vital macromolecules (e.g., nucleic acids). Their biological significance is not quite clear. The enzyme system which metabolizes numerous drugs, pesticides, as well as other endogenous and exogenous substrates, is responsible for both the activation and detoxification of carcinogenic chemicals. The delicate balance between these 2 processes of opposing toxicological consequence is determined by genetic and environmental factors. Depending upon the metabolic profile of chemicals, certain compounds are carcinogenic in 1 animal species while not in others. The manipulation of their metabolism by physiological (e.g., stress) or pharmacological (e.g., inducers or inhibitors of microsomal enzymes) means can result in a profound change of various biological actions of chemicals (e.g., cytotoxicity, carcinogenicity and mutagenicity). To ascertain that potential toxicological hazards to human health by animal drugs and feed additives will be recognized during the phase of testing, appropriate test animals have to be selected with great care. It is indispensible that the metabolic break-down of the investigational substance proceeds via similar pathways in both test animals and the target species. This will assure that the same metabolities to which man might be exposed will have ample opportunity to exert their possible adverse effects to the experimental animals during a life-long feeding of the test subtance. It can with a reasonable certainty be assumed that in experiments performed under such precautionary measures, toxico-pharmacological properties relevant to human safety evaluation will not remain undetected.

column4: SIMONAITIS, RA; CAIL, RS; ZEHNER, JM; BRY, RE
column5: GAS-LIQUID-CHROMATOGRAPHIC DETERMINATION OF M-PHENOXYBENZYL CIS, TRANS-(+/-)-3-(2,2-DICHLOROVINYL)-2,2-DIMETHYLCYCLOPROPANECARBOXYLATE IN AQUEOUS FORMULATIONS
column7: JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION OF OFFICIAL ANALYTICAL CHEMISTS
column12: A simple and rapid GLC method was developed for the analysis of aqueous solutions of [the insecticide] FMC 33297 (m-phenoxybenzyl cis,trans-(.+-.)-3-(2,2-dichlorovinyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate). The compound is extracted from aqueous solution with benzene and cleaned up by liquid chromatography. The sample extracts are analyzed by GLC with a flame ionization detector and quantitated by comparing integrator counts of extracts with those of standards. Recoveries of FMC 33297 were 90-100%. The method has good precision (the SD for 4 deteminations of a 0.002394% formulation was 6 .times. 10-6) and is sensitive to 0.00004% active ingredient by weight.

column5: COMPARISON OF GRANULAR AND TRANSPLANT WATER APPLICATIONS OF NON-FUMIGANT NEMATICIDES FOR CONTROLLING STING NEMATODE, BELONOLAIMUS-LONGICAUDATUS, ON CABBAGE
column7: SOIL AND CROP SCIENCE SOCIETY OF FLORIDA PROCEEDINGS
column12: In a series of 4 experiments conducted during 1972-75, a comparison was made of the effectiveness of the nonfumigant nematocides carbofuran, ethoprop, fensulfothion, oxamyl and phenamiphos when applied in-the-row as incorporated granular formulations and as liquid formulations in the transplant water for controlling the sting nematide, Belonolaimus longicaudatus Rau, 1958, on cabbage, Brassica oleracea var. capitata L. All nematocides were applied at 2.24 kg a.i.[active ingredient]/ha. The granules were applied in 38 cm bands and incorporated 5-7 cm deep just prior to transplanting, and the liquid formulations added to the transplant water which was applied in 25 cm bands over the row at the rate of 776 ml/m of row. All the nematocides greatly reduced nematode populations and significantly increased cabbage yields in the experiments where initial nematode populations were high. Nematode control and yield response were similar for the 2 methods of application when the data from all experiments were averaged.

column5: RESPONSE OF HELA-CELLS TO SELECTED PESTICIDES AND HALLUCINOGENS
column12: Monolayer cultures of HeLa cells were used to monitor the effect of 5 liquid commercial insecticidal formulations (Raid, Isotox, Sevin, Ortho-Klor 74, and Malathion 50), and 2 pure hallucinogenic chemicals (LSD, LSD and .DELTA.-9-tetrahydrocannabinol [.DELTA.-9-THC]). HeLa cells were incubated for 48 h with different concentrations of the selected formulations or chemicals, after which the effect on cell culture growth was determined. Ortho-Klor 74 was the most toxic of the formulations or hallucinogens used in that it was 100.0% lethal to the HeLa cells at a concentration of 0.015 2 ml of liquid formulation/ml of cell growth medium (.mu.l/ml). When HeLa cells were exposed to the same low concentration (0.015 .mu.l/ml) of Raid, Isotox, and Malathion 50, cell numbers increased. Sevin had no effect on cell numbers at 0.015 .mu.l/ml but enhanced cell numbers at 1.5 .mu.l/ml. The lowest tested concentrations of the 2 hallucinogens produced no stimulation in cell number. As the concentrations of each formulation or hallucinogen were increased, the number of cells decreased. .DELTA.-9-THC (1.0 .mu.l/ml) was 7 times more toxic to HeLa cells than LSD (at 1.0 .mu.g/ml.). The investigated concentrations of each formulation or pure compound that had the least toxicity to the HeLa cells when compared to untreated controls was then used in further experiments to monitor the chemical''s effect on trichloroacetic acid precipitable nucleic acids and protein following a 48 h incubation period with appropriate radioactive precursors and chemicals. When HeLa cells were exposed to Raid, Isotox, and Malathion 50 at 0.015 .mu.l/ml and Sevin at 1.5 .mu.l/ml, the quantities of RNA, DNA, and protein in the HeLa cells increased. Both LSD (7.5 .mu.g/ml) and .DELTA.-9-THC (1.0 .mu.g/ml) profoundly decreased HeLa cell nucleic acids and protein.

column4: SANDERS, PL; BURPEE, LL; COLE, H; DUICH, JM
column5: CONTROL OF PYTHIUM BLIGHT OF TURFGRASS WITH CGA-48988
column12: The efficacy of the experimental systemic fungicide N-(2,6-dimethylphenyl)-N-(methoxyacetyl)alanine methyl ester (CGA-48988) was tested in vitro against 23 Pythium spp., and in the greenhouse and field against Pythium foliar blight on ryegrass and creeping bentgrass. The chemical was uniformly effective in vitro against all 23 Pythium isolates, with ED50 of 1 .mu.g or less/ml potato-dextrose agar (PDA). CGA-48988 was evaluated in greenhouse and field experiments as both wettable powder and granular formulations. In greenhouse tests, the chemical was applied to pot-grown, seedling bentgrass at rates of 1.8, 3.6, 7, 14, 28 and 56 g active ingredient (a.i.)/93 m2. In the field, mature ryegrass was treated with 14, 28, 56 and 84 g a.i./93 m2. Both formulations prevented the development of Pythium blight symptoms in the field and greenhouse when inoculation immediately followed treatment. Residual efficacy was more persistent in greenhouse tests than in the field. CGA-48988 at 14 and 28 g a.i./93 m2 provided satisfactory symptom suppression for 7 wk after treatment in the greenhouse. In field tests, all rates of CGA-48988 provided complete symptom suppression at 2 wk after treatment. By 3 wk after treatment, there was no commercially adequate disease suppression in the field.

column5: SIDE-EFFECTS OF THE HERBICIDE 2,4,5-T AFFECTING MOBILITY AND MORTALITY OF THE SPRINGTAIL ONYCHIURUS-QUADRIOCELLATUS GISIN (COLLEMBOLA)
column7: ZEITSCHRIFT FUR ANGEWANDTE ENTOMOLOGIE-JOURNAL OF APPLIED ENTOMOLOGY
column12: The herbicide 2,4,5-T is widely used in forestry and nature reserves against black cherry (Prunus serotina) and birch (Betula spp.). When adult specimens of the springtail O. quadriocellatus were continuously exposed to the herbicide in the lab, a dose of 0.003 ml/dm2 caused a significant increase in mortality. The active ingredient of the herbicide (2,4,5-T isooctylester) and the formulation fluid itself proved to be toxic. The toxic action of the herbicide is mainly caused by direct contact; there was only a slight effect after application as a vapor. Juvenile springtails proved more susceptible than adults. The herbicide also influenced the mobility of the springtails. A high dose (0.025 ml/dm2) decreased mobility, and a low dose (0.003 ml/dm2) increased mobility. The herbicide had a repellent action on springtails; these were able to avoid treated sections of the substrate, and to escape from them. In spite of this repellency a considerable proportion of the springtails tested died, although given the opportunity to escape. They died on the treated substrate or after escape from it. The amounts of herbicide on the soil under and between black cherry shrubs after practical applications varied from 0.0005-0.017 ml/dm2. Side effects of the herbicide 2,4,5-T should be expected in the field.

column4: ALDRIDGE, WN; MILES, JW; MOUNT, DL; VERSCHOYLE, RD
column5: TOXICOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF IMPURITIES IN MALATHION
column12: During a malaria eradication program in Pakistan in 1976, out of 7500 spraymen, 2800 became poisoned and 5 died. The major determinant of this poisoning was identified as isomalathion present an an impurity in the insecticide malathion. The isomalathion was apparently produced during storage of the formulated malathion. The quantitative correlation found between isomalathion content and toxicity of many field samples of malathion was confirmed by an examination of mixtures of pure compounds. Addition of known amounts of isomalathion to technical malathion indicated that other active substances were present. These impurities were identified (trimethyl phosphorothioates) and behaved like isomalathion in potentiating the toxicity of malathion. Some preliminary work on their toxicological properties is reported. The mechanisms involved in the potentiation of the toxicity of malathion are discussed.

column5: COMPARISON OF THE EFFECTS OF 2 DERIVATIVES OF PICOLINIC-ACID HERBICIDES ON PINUS-RADIATA AND EUCALYPTUS-VIMINALIS
column12: The effects of the 2 commercial herbicides, Tordon 22K and Tordon 50D, on P. radiata seed germination and subsequent seedling growth and their toxicities to P. radiata and E. viminalis seedlings were examined in relation to the type and formulation of their active ingredients. Tordon 22K is the potassium salt of 4-amino-3,5,6-trichloropicolinic acid and Tordon 50D is made up of 1 part triisopropanolamine salt of 4-amino-3,5,6-trichloropicolinic acid to 4 parts 2,4-D. There was no evidence that differences in the formulation of picloram in either herbicide influenced differences in the toxicities of these preparations to P. radiata seedlings. Wtih 1 exception (the toxicity of Tordon 22K to E. viminalis seedlings), the herbicidal effects of Tordon 22K and Tordon 50D could be explained in terms of their active constituents, picloram and 2,4-D. Tordon 22K was considerably more toxic to eucalypt seedlings than solutions containing its active ingredient, picloram.

column4: MURUGESAN, S; PARAMESWARAN, S; BALASUBRAMANIAN, M
column5: FIELD EVALUATION OF SOME INSECTICIDAL TREATMENTS FOR CONTROL OF COTTON STEM WEEVIL, PEMPHERULUS-AFFINIS (FST)
column12: Field experiments were conducted on the control of cotton stem weevil P. affinis with Gossypium hirsutum variety MCU. 5 cotton using granular insecticides and spray formulation insecticides. Results revealed that a single soil application of any of the granular insecticides aldicarb 10G, carbofuran 3G, disulfoton 5G or phorate 10G at 1.0 kg ai[active ingredient]/ha 1 wk after sowing around the plants or spraying 4 times on the 15th, 30th, 45th and 60th day of sowing with fenvalerate 0.075 kg/ha or monocrotophos 0.375 kg/ha was effective in minimizing the stem weevil infestation.

column5: EFFICACY OF POSTEMERGENCE INSECTICIDE APPLICATIONS AGAINST THE SOUTHERN CORN BILLBUG (COLEOPTERA, CURCULIONIDAE) ON CORN
column7: JOURNAL OF THE GEORGIA ENTOMOLOGICAL SOCIETY
column12: Postemergence applications of 6 insecticides were evaluated for control of S. callosus (Olivier) on corn. Chemicals, formulations and rates (kg AI[active ingredient]/ha) effecting a significant decrease in seedling injury were terbufos 15G and carbofuran 4F, each at 1.12, 1.68 and 2.24 kg; phorate 15G at 1.68 kg; chlorpyrifos 15G at 1.68 and 2.24 kg; and chlorpyrifos 4E at 2.24 kg. Carbofuran 10G at 1.12, 1.68 and 2.24 kg; fenvalarate 1G at 0.22 kg; and Penncap-M (methyl parathion) 2F at 1.12 kg failed to provide significant control.

column4: PAPAVIZAS, GC; SCHWENK, FW; LOCKE, JC; LEWIS, JA
column5: SYSTEMIC FUNGICIDES FOR CONTROLLING PHYTOPHTHORA ROOT-ROT AND DAMPING-OFF OF SOYBEAN
column12: Technical 5-ethoxy-3-(trichloromethyl)-1,2,4-thiadiazole (ETMT) applied to soybean seed with an organic solvent (acetone or dichloromethane) significantly reduced root rot and damping-off caused by P. megasperma var. sojae (Pms). Commerically formulated ETMT (25 EC) added directly to the seed did not reduce disease. The experimental fungicide propyl [3-(dimethylamino)propyl]carbamate HCl (SN66752) applied to the seed directly or with a solvent (water, acetone, dichloromethane) reduced postemergence damping-off and mean root rot severity on surviving plants. Seed infusion with SN66752 in a solvent was more effective than direct application at 2.8 g active ingredient/kg seed. The experimental fungicide N-(2,6-dimethylphenyl)-N-(methoxyacetyl)alanine methyl ester (metalaxyl) (CGA-48988) significantly reduced disease, regardless of method of application. Seed treatment with ETMT, SN66752, or metalaxyl did not affect plant emergence, plant height and fresh or dry root weight in pasteurized soil. Dry weight of vines from the nontreated control was lower than that of vines from the seed treatments. None of the 3 fungicides added to soybean seeds directly or with acetone significantly reduced Pms of increased yields in the field in Kansas [USA] in 2 consecutive yr.

column5: GREEN LACEWINGS (NEUROPTERA, CHRYSOPIDAE) OF COTTON FIELDS IN CENTRAL RHODESIA .1. BIOLOGY OF CHRYSOPA-BONINENSIS OKOMOTO AND TOXICITY OF CERTAIN INSECTICIDES TO THE LARVA
column12: In egg collections from unsprayed cotton fields C. boninensis Okomoto was the most common species of this genus and comprised 81% of all fertile eggs. In rearing larvae for insecticide bioassays, data were collected on its life history and feeding habits. The mean duration of the egg, larval and pupal stages at 25.degree. C was 3.7; 12.0 and 10.0 days, respectively. Under laboratory conditions adult females lived an average of 31.4 days (maximum 106 days) while males lived for 21.0 days (maximum 111 days). The larvae accumulate and carry debris composed of exoskeletal remains of dead prey on their backs and they feed on a wide variety of soft-bodied insects and eggs of Lepidoptera. The adults are not predacious. A bioassay method was developed which determined the effects of dried residues of commerical formulations of insecticides on 3rd instar larvae during 24 h of contact at 25.degree. C. The larvae were almost immune to carbaryl (LC50 = 4.39% active ingredient) but were very susceptible to DDT [LC50 = 0.07944% (active ingredient)] endosulfan (LC50 = 1.349% a.i.) and dimethoate (LC50 = 0.26% a.i.) were other insecticides tested.

column5: EFFECT OF PHENAMIPHOS ON HETERODERA-SCHACHTII AND MELOIDOGYNE-JAVANICA
column12: Aqueous solutions of technical-grade phenamiphos [ethyl 3-methyl-4-(methylthio) phenyl (1-methylethyl) phosphoramidate] were used in hatching chambers to test the effect of phenamiphos on hatching and movement of M. javanica and H. schachtii. Hatch of M. javanica and H. schachtii eggs was depressed 70 and 88% by nematicide at 0.48 and 4.80 .mu.g/ml, respectively. Infectivity of 2nd-stage larvae of both species was affected by concentrations as low as 0.01 .mu.g/ml. At least 0.5 .mu.g/ml was required to decrease the larvae movement of both. To decrease the movement of H. schachtii males toward females, 10 .mu.g/ml was required. In a field experiment using a 15% granular formulation, 5 kg/ha active ingredient significantly reduced infection of sugarbeet roots by H. schachtii.

column5: CONTROL OF RICE LEAF-FOLDER BY GRANULAR INSECTICIDES
column12: Field studies on the control of rice leaf-folder (C. medinalis Guenee) with granular formulations of gamma-BHC, chlorfenvinphos, mephosfolan, quinalphos and carbofuran applied in standing water at 0.75, 1.00 and 1.25 kg ai[active ingredient]/ha during winter season (rabi) 1978 and 1979 indicated that mephosfolan was most effective (> 90%) and was on a par with carbofuran. Chlorfenvinphos and quinalphos were less effective, whereas gamma-BHC gave maximum infestation. All the insecticides at 1.25 kg ai/ha reduced significantly the pest infestation compared with other dosages.

column4: YAMAMOTO, S; NISHIDA, A; AOKI, A
column5: ACARICIDAL STUDIES ON MILBEMYCINS, A NEW FAMILY OF MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS .1. ACARICIDAL PROPERTIES AND CONTROL EFFECTIVENESS AGAINST THE 2-SPOTTED SPIDER-MITE, TETRANYCHUS-URTICAE KOCH AND THE CITRUS RED MITE, PANONYCHUS-CITRI MCGREGOR (ACARINA, TETRANYCHIDAE)
column7: JAPANESE JOURNAL OF APPLIED ENTOMOLOGY AND ZOOLOGY
column12: Several preparations of milbemycins obtained from Streptomyces hygroscopicus ssp. aureolacrimosus were evaluated for their acaricidal effect. Three fractions, A3 .cntdot. A4, B2 .cntdot. B3 and C1 .cntdot. C2 mixtures, were highly effective against all the stages of the two-spotted spider mite and the motile stage of the citrus red mite in the laboratory. Young eggs of the citrus red mite were much less sensitive to these fractions as well as to the other fractions. The effect of a crude preparation of milbemycins, the brown oily mixture (BOM), exerted the same effect as that with all fractions. Sublethal doses of the effective fractions and of BOM caused anesthesia in adult mites from which they recovered. BOM was decomposed by sunlight and its residual effect was unstable on cowpea leaves even under dark conditions. BOM and petroleum oil showed synergistic activity against the eggs of the citrus red mite in the laboratory. The diluent of a single EC [emulsifiable concentrate] formulation containing both BOM (0.02%) and petroleum oil (0.2%) as active ingredients was effective in controlling field populations of the citrus red mite when sprayed in mandarin orange orchards. Populations of the 2-spotted spider mite on kidney bean plants in a green house were also controlled by EC formulation containing only BOM.

column4: NAKAMURA, T; SHIMIZU, H; FUJIMOTO, M; TAKAHI, Y; KONDO, Y
column5: STUDIES ON PESTICIDAL SUSPENSION CONCENTRATES .1. THE INFLUENCE OF PARTICLE-SIZE ON EFFECTIVENESS OF PENTACHLOROBENZYL ALCOHOL TO RICE BLAST AND PREPARATION OF THE SUSPENSION CONCENTRATE
column12: The effectiveness of pentachlorobenzyl alcohol (PCBA) in controlling rice blast was increased progressively by reduction of the particle size in formulations. For good biological performance, the particle size had to be < 5 .mu.m in diameter. To achieve such fine particle size, wet-grinding with an agitator mill, Attritor, proved superior to dry-grinding with an air mill, Jet-O-Mizer. Technical grade PCBA was easily ground with an Attritor to particles < 2 .mu.m as median diameter; most of the particles were < 5 .mu.m in diameter. PCBA suspension concentrates were prepared by wet-grinding with an Attritor. The controlled flocculation of particles was necessary to prevent the hard caking of PCBA particles caused by free sedimentation in suspension concentrates. Flocculation was controlled by adjusting both particle size and the amount of sodium lignosulfonate added as a dispersant. Such a formulation was physically stable for at least 5 yr.

column5: THE INFLUENCE OF FUNGICIDES ON POLLEN GERMINATION AND YIELD OF CRANBERRY
column7: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR HORTICULTURAL SCIENCE
column12: Captan, catptafol and mancozeb at 10.mu.g, and cupric hydroxide, ferbam, triforine-EC [emulsifiable concentrate] and zineb at 100 .mu.g active ingredient [a.i.]/ml of glucose-amended cornmeal agar completely inhibited pollen germination of ''McFarlin'' cranberry (V. macrocarpon Ait.). Triforine-F [flowable] and triforine-WP [wettable product] at 10,00 .mu.g/ml allowed some pollen germination. Captafol, mancozeb and the 3 formulations of triforine all prevented pollen germination when suspensions, each at the concentration for field application, were spread on the surface of the medium immediately prior to seeding with pollen. Pollen failed to germinate on stigmas of cranberry flowers previously dipped into suspensions containing 10,000 .mu.g/ml of captafol, cupric hydroxide, ferbam and triforine-EC. Lower concentrations of these 4 fungicides and 5 others at 10,000 .mu.g/ml had little or no effect on pollen germination in vivo. Triforine-EC applied twice during bloom at 0.33 kg a.i./ha significantly (P = 5%) reduced yield by 41%. While triforine-EC did not alter the number of berries produced per upright, it resulted in the production of smaller and lighter berries.

column5: RESIDUAL EFFECTIVENESS OF POSTEMERGENCE BAND APPLICATIONS OF INSECTICIDES AGAINST THE SOUTHERN CORN BILLBUG (COLEOPTERA, CURCULIONIDAE) ON CORN
column7: JOURNAL OF THE GEORGIA ENTOMOLOGICAL SOCIETY
column12: Selected rates and formulations of chlorpyrifos, terbufos and carbofuran were evaluated for residual efficacy against the southern corn billbug, S. callosus (Olivier). Billbugs were introduced into treated plots immediately, 5, 10, 21 and 23 days after treatment. All treatments were effective initially. Residual activity was greatest for chlorpyrifos 15G (1.12, 1.68 and 2.24 kg AI[active ingredient]/ha), and least for those rates of carbofuran 4F.

column5: STIMULATION OF AUTOTROPHIC AMMONIUM OXIDATION IN RICE RHIZOSPHERE SOIL BY THE INSECTICIDE CARBOFURAN
column12: The application of the insecticide carbofuran (technical or formulated) to rice rhizosphere soil suspensions at 10 and 100 ppm (.mu.g/ml) of active ingredient distinctly stimulated the autotrophic oxidation of ammonium. Evidence suggested that Nitrosomonas sp. was enriched in the presence of carbofuran. Formulated carbofuran (Furadan 3G) exhibited a more pronounced stimulation of ammonium oxidation than that exhibited by the technical-grade (99.5%) carbofuran, a result which was attributed to the CaCO3 present in the formulation.

column5: THE INFLUENCE OF TEMPERATURE ON THE DISEASE RATE OF BARLEY LEAF STRIPE (DRECHSLERA-GRAMINEA) AND THE EFFECT OF NON-MERCURIAL DRESSINGS
column7: ZEITSCHRIFT FUR PFLANZENKRANKHEITEN UND PFLANZENSCHUTZ-JOURNAL OF PLANT DISEASES AND PROTECTION
column12: Changeover to the use of non-mercurials for cereal seed treatment created a special problem associated with the control of barley leaf stripe because activity of the pathogen of this disease can be restricted satisfactorily only by use of specific fungicides. Use of seed dressings not containing a specific anti-leaf stripe component would enhance the economic importance of the disease in the future. The extent of leaf stripe occurrence greatly depends upon temperature levels during the germination phase under conditions of natural seed contamination. A temperature of 2.degree. C maintained over a period of 21 days is optimal for seedling infection. At tempertures exceeding 6.degree. C, the likelihood of an infection successfully taking place is considerably less. At 10.degree. C and above, the susceptible stage of the seedling is too short for a severe infection to occur. A distinct time factor is evident also at low temperatures, with severe infection occurring only after a germination period of at least 14 days. Changing pregermination temperatures have a positive effect on infection level. A temperature rhythm of 10.degree. C C/2.degree. C per 24-h period resulted in infection rates being obtained after 13 days that were comparable with those recorded at a constant temperature of 2.degree. C after 21 days of pregermination. The post-infectional growth temperature has little influence on the development of symptoms on the leaves. For routine testing of compounds for the control of D. graminea, it is, therefore, recommended to pregerminate naturally infected seed at 2.degree. C for 21 days, followed by greenhouse cultivation at an average temperature of 18.degree. C. Under these follow-up conditions, assessable symptoms appear after a further 21 days. The seed dressings Panoctin UTB and Baytan U were evaluated for efficacy under optimal infection conditions in greenhouse tests. Whereas infections of up to 55% occurred on untreated seed, only Panoctin UTB gave over 95% control at the normal rate of use; thus, the formulation containing imazalil proved to be somewhat superior. In 2-yr field trials, all approved non-mercurial seed dressings effective against leaf stripe were tested together with a number of experimental formulations at graded dosage rates. Applied at normal rates of use, all approved seed dressings gave satisfactory control of .gtoreq. 95%. There were, however, marked differences among the tested products especially at reduced active ingredient doses. Therefore, greater attention must be paid in future to careful application of seed dressings.

column5: GREEN LACEWINGS (NEUROPTERA, CHRYSOPIDAE) OF COTTON FIELDS IN CENTRAL ZIMBABWE .2. BIOLOGY OF CHRYSOPA-CONGRUA WALKER AND CHRYSOPA-PUDICA NAVAS AND TOXICITY OF CERTAIN INSECTICIDES TO THEIR LARVAE
column12: Collections from unsprayed cotton fields at Gatooma revealed that the 2 less common species of lacewings: C. congrua Walker and C. pudica Navas accounted for 15 and 10%, respectively, of all fertile eggs. While rearing larvae of both species for insecticide bioassays, data were collected on their life history and feeding habits. At 25.degree. C the mean duration of the egg, larval and pupal stages of C. congrua was 4.0; 13.8 and 10.2 days, respectively, while for C. pudica the same stages lasted an average of 4.0; 12.6 and 10.1 days. In an insectary, adult females of C. congrua lived for an average of 55.0 days (maximum 150 days) while males lived for 40.4 days (maximum 157 days). For C. pudica females and males the respective mean durations were 50.6 days (maximum 159 days) and 59.4 days (maximum 138 days). The larvae do not carry any debris but both species exhibit a marked thigmotactic response. They feed on a variety of soft-bodied insects and the eggs of Lepidoptera but the adults are not predacious. The effects of dried residues of commercial formulations of insecticides on the 3rd instar larvae during 24 h of contact at 25.degree. C were determined. The least toxic insecticide was endosulfan (LC50 = 1.161% active ingredient (a.i.) for C. congrua and 1.209% a.i. for C. pudica) while the most toxic was DDT (LC50 = 0.004 65% a.i. and 0.015 23% a.i., respectively). Dimethoate (LC50 = 0.104 7% a.i. and 0.342 5% a.i.) and carbaryl (LC50 = 0.015 03% a.i and 0.016 6% a.i.) were other insecticides bioassayed.

column5: LIQUID-CHROMATOGRAPHY OF LIQUID FORMULATIONS CONTAINING 2,4-DICHLOROPHENOXYACETIC ACID, DICAMBA, AND 2-(2-METHYL-4-CHLOROPHENOXY)PROPIONIC ACID AS THEIR SALTS
column7: JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION OF OFFICIAL ANALYTICAL CHEMISTS
column12: A high pressure liquid chromatographic method was developed for liquid herbicide combinations that contain different combinations of 3 active ingredients including 2,4-D, 2-(2-methyl-4-chlorophenoxy)propionic acid (MCPP) and dicamba. A reverse phase column in the ion suppression mode and a binary solvent system separate all 3 herbicides quantitatively on a single chromatogram. The internal standard solution may contain 2 internal standards, salicylic acid and butyrophenone, for use with certain combinations of the herbicides. The solvent system resolves the compounds of interest from all significant impurities.

column4: ROSS, DJ; SPEIR, TW; COWLING, JC; WHALE, KN
column5: INFLUENCE OF FIELD APPLICATIONS OF OXAMYL AND FENAMIPHOS ON BIOCHEMICAL ACTIVITIES OF SOIL UNDER PASTURE
column12: The influence of commercial formulations of the systemic nematocides and the insecticides, oxamyl and fenamiphos on soil biochemical properties was studied under field conditions with a Typic Haplaquoll under grass-clover pasture. Application rates per hectare, in spring, were 12.7 kg a.i. [active ingredient] oxamyl and 18.6 kg a.i. fenamiphos. Results are reported for 5 collections of topsoil sampled 1-18 wk after application of the nematocides. Neither nematocide had any significant influence on rates of CO2 and net mineral-N (Min-N) production, 2 indices of microbial biomass (biomass C and Min-N flush contents), or invertase, amylase, urease and phosphatase activities. Only sulfatase activity was significantly depressed, in the fenamiphos-treated soil. Cellulase activity was significantly enhanced, particularly by the fenamiphos treatment. Indirect plant effects, following initial scorching and subsequent increased production of herbage in the treated plots, could have been responsible for the increase in soil cellulase activity. Generally, it appears that neither nematicide would have any deleterious effects on these soil biochemical properties under temperate field conditions.

column5: LIQUID-CHROMATOGRAPHIC AND GAS-CHROMATOGRAPHIC DETERMINATION OF N-NITROSODIETHANOLAMINE IN 2,4-D DIETHANOLAMINE PESTICIDE FORMULATIONS
column7: JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION OF OFFICIAL ANALYTICAL CHEMISTS
column12: A method for the determination of N-nitrosodiethanolamine (NDElA) in diethanolamine formulations of 2,4-D herbicide has been developed. The NDElA fraction was isolated from the formulation by 2 disposable ion exchange columns followed by an extraction column to remove the acid and amine that might be deleterious to the analytical system and to concentrate the NDElA solution. The isolated fraction was then further purified on a silica gel disposable column and analyzed for NDElA by using a liquid chromatographic (LC) apparatus connected to an ultraviolet (UV) detector in series with a thermal energy analyzer (TEA) detector. NDElA was derivatized to the trimethylsilyl (TMS) derivative, the identity of which was confirmed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) and analyzed by gas chromatography with TEA detection (GC-TEA). The limit of detection of NDElA by LC-TEA and LC-UV is 1 ng and by GC-TEA 0.08 ng. These values correspond to 0.1 ppm relative to the active ingredient in the formulation. The recoveries for this analytical method averaged from 91 to 100% when the samples were spiked at the 0.30-3.47 ppm level. The specificity and reproducibility of these 3 methods of determination were compared; results suggest that NDElA was not generated during cleanup or in the GC injection port.

column4: HILLS, FJ; NIKOLICH, GA; LEACH, LD
column5: STEROL-INHIBITING FUNGICIDES FOR CONTROL OF SUGAR-BEET POWDERY MILDEW, METHODS AND RATES OF APPLICATION AND EVIDENCE OF GROWTH-REGULATION
column12: Trials were conducted to evaluate various rates and methods of applying 3 sterol-inhibiting fungicides; triadimefon, nuarimol, and propiconazol [against Erysiphe polygoni]. Crown sprays, and especially crown-applied granules, generally provided superior season-long control compared with broadcast applications. Rate of application of crown-applied materials was related negatively to disease severity, with 0.56 kg a.i. ha [active ingredient] providing consistently effective long-term disease suppression. Results suggest that a slow-release granular formulation applied to crowns may improve the duration of disease control. Triadimefon or nuarimol granules applied at 1.12 kg a.i./ha gave significantly higher yields than did biweekly S treatments even though disease levels were comparable. This indicates that these fungicides may have a growth-promoting effect.

column5: PROTECTIVE EFFECT OF FUNGICIDES ON CORN SEED STORED WITH LOW AND HIGH MOISTURE CONTENTS
column12: Storage tests were carried out on the effect of fungicides on the viability of maize [Zea mays] seed stored at 75% and 85% relative humidity (RH). In the first test, maize seeds at 99% germination and 9.6% moisture content were inoculated with spores of the Aspergillus glaucus group, treated with 750 ppm of active material of fungicide (benomyl, captan, captafol, chlorothalonil, carbendazim plus maneb, dichlofluanid and thiabendazole), and stored at 75% RH and 26.degree. C. A germination of 68 to 90% was obtained in treated seeds at 330 days compared to 61% in the control. In the second test, maize seeds at 16.5% moisture content were treated with 5 fungicides (benomyl, captafol, captan, chlorothalonil, thiabendazole) and a commercial mixture of carbendazim plus maneb, as well as with 15 mixtures between these products. The seed treatment rate was 750 ppm of active ingredient for the individual products and 375 ppm of each product in the mixture of 2 fungicides. Germination of the untreated seed after 120 days was 16%, while the treated seeds germinated between 24 and 90%. Some of the fungicide mixtures were better than the individual fungicides for controlling fungi and maintaining seed viability.

column4: TANIZAWA, K; FUJIMOTO, M; KAWAKUBO, K; KASAI, F; HONMA, T; NAKAMURA, T
column5: STUDIES ON PYRAZOLATE FORMULATION .2. INFLUENCE OF THE PARTICLE-SIZE ON THE HERBICIDAL EFFICACY OF PYRAZOLATE
column12: Relationship between the particle size and the herbicidal activity of pyrazolate was investigated under paddy field conditions. Suspensions containing pyrazolate particles classified into different sizes were tested in a greenhouse. By pre-emergence application, fractions less than 44 .mu.m in diameter were effective against Sagittaria pygmaea at a dose of 0.5 kg/ha, while particles larger than 20 .mu.m were not active enough against Echinochloa oryzicola at the same dose. Pyrazolate larger than 10 .mu.m in diameter gave unsatisfactory efficacy against Cyperus serotinus even at a dose of 1 kg/ha. As pyrazolate got coarse, the activity decreased more remarkably by post-emergence application. Granules containing 10% pyrazolate were prepared by an extrusion method with the active ingredient pulverized into 1.36, 1.76, 2.03, 2.15, 5.13, or 7.47 m2/g of a specific surface area (Sw) and applied into pots and paddy fields. In the pot tests, granules containing the coarsest pyrazolate were less effective than others. In the field, granules containing pyrazolate of 2.03 or 2.15 m2/g of Sw were more effective than those containing either coarser or finer pyrazolate. The results indicate that the herbicidal efficacy of pyrazolate is affected by its particle size, and that pyrazolate should be pulverized into ca. 2 m2/g of Sw in order to demonstrate sufficient activity in paddy fields in granule form.

column4: BELLINDER, RR; LYONS, RE; SCHECKLER, SE; WILSON, HP
column5: CELLULAR ALTERATIONS RESULTING FROM FOLIAR APPLICATIONS OF HOE-39866
column12: Formulated and technical grade HOE-39866 [ammonium-(3-amino-3-carboxypropyl)methylphosphinate] at concentrations of 10-1, 10-2, and 10-3 M were applied to leaf blade tissues of nonreproductive adult redroot pigweed (Amaranthus retroflexus L. #3 AMARE) and fall panicum (Panicum dichotomiflorum Michx. # PANDI). Tissues were sampled at regular intervals after treatment and prepared for light microscopic examination. The major response of both species involved rupture and contortion of the interveinal mesophyll cells with concomitant disorganization of the bundle sheath cells. Rapid epidermal collapse occurred in redroot pigweed but not in fall panicum. The absence of adjuvants resulted in nonuniform symptom expression as herbicide droplets accumulated in depressions and along leaf margins. No other adjuvant-specific effect was observed. herbicide concentration did not alter the final response but the time-to-expression increased as concentration decreased.

column4: BAHADIR, M; PFISTER, G; LORENZ, W; HERRMANN, R; KORTE, F
column5: FIELD TRIALS WITH DESMETRYN CONTAINING COVER AND MULCH SHEETS TO CONTROL WEEDS IN WHITE CABBAGE CULTIVATION
column7: ZEITSCHRIFT FUR PFLANZENKRANKHEITEN UND PFLANZENSCHUTZ-JOURNAL OF PLANT DISEASES AND PROTECTION
column12: The control of weeds in white cabbage cultivation by application of plastic cover and mulch sheets, which had the herbicide desmetryn incorporated in various concentrations, was tested in field trials. The active agent, homogeneously dissolved in the polymer matrix, was completely released during a period of about 22 days at maximum. A concentration of about 0.1% desmetryn in the sheets was already effective against locally growing weeds and test seeds, however, for a fully satisfying weed control 0.2% corresponding to 1.6 kg/ha was necessary. A direct comparison of herbicidal activity with the conventionally sprayed desmetryn formulation Semeron 25 was impossible, because the applied amounts as recommended by the manufacturer, gave no significant herbicidal effect. The treatment with 0.2% incorporated desmetryn gave 68% higher yields of cabbage when applied in cover sheets and 52% in mulch sheets, compared to the herbicide untreated control plots. The cabbage plants grown with mulch sheets seemed to be more affected by the released herbicide than those with sheet covering. This effect may be caused by intensified flushing of desmetryn into the planting openings in these sheets during rainfalls. Residues of desmetryn in the field crops were only found in the range of about 30 .mu.g/kg when treated with highly overdosed amounts of 1% of the herbicide in covering sheets. Treatments with concentrations of 0.2% and higher led to residues in soil, preferably in the upper 5 cm layer, from 12 .mu.g/kg up to 51 .mu.g/kg with cover sheets and up to 311 .mu.g/kg with mulch sheets.

column5: EFFECT OF GLYPHOSATE, HEXAZINONE AND TRICLOPYR ON INVITRO GROWTH OF 5 SPECIES OF ECTOMYCORRHIZAL FUNGI
column12: In vitro growth tests with glyphosate (RoundupR), hexazinone (liquid Velpar L.R and granule PrononeTM5GR) and trichlopyr (GarlonR) on five species of ectomycorrhizal fungi (Hebeloma crustuliniforme, Laccaria laccata, Thelophora americana, T. terrestris and Suillus tomentosus) showed varied species sensitivity to different concentrations of herbicides. Fungal growth was significantly (P = 0.05) reduced particularly at concentrations above 10 ppm. Garlon with tricolopyr as a.i. [active ingredient] was the most toxic of the four herbicide formulations.

column4: PRADEEPKUMAR, N; SABESAN, S; KUPPUSAMY, M; BALARAMAN, K
column5: EFFECT OF CONTROLLED RELEASE FORMULATION OF BACILLUS-SPHAERICUS ON MANSONIA BREEDING
column12: A briquette formulation of B. sphaericus was evaluated for its efficacy in controlling the larvae of Mansonia mosquitoes breeding in the ponds of coconut plantations in Shertallai, Kerala state. Three doses of the formulation were tested viz., 7.5 kg active ingredient (ai)/hectare (ha), 15 kg ai/ha and 30 kg ai/ha. The larval population in the treated and untreated ponds was monitored before and after application of the formulation. The Mansonia larval population was reduced considerably in the ponds treated with 15 and 30 kg ai/ha. Reduction in the larval population was first noticed four days after application. The bacterial pesticide was more effective on early instar larvae than on late instars. The formulation exerted residual larvicidal activity for 31 days.

column5: FIELD - OUTDOOR LYSIMETER - CLOSED CULTIVATION CHAMBER - COMPARATIVE STUDIES WITH LINDANE AFTER SPRAY APPLICATION ON POTATO PLANTS
column7: ZEITSCHRIFT FUR PFLANZENKRANKHEITEN UND PFLANZENSCHUTZ-JOURNAL OF PLANT DISEASES AND PROTECTION
column12: To evaluate pesticide with respect to its behaviour in the environment, it is necessary to use 14C-labelled active ingredients in model experiments. Such studies can be performed in outdoor lysimeters and closed, controlled ventilated vegetation chambers. Spray application of [14C]lindane, formulated as Nexit-fluid, on high grown potato plants in both systems and attempted identical application of unlabelled lindane in the field delivered data suitable for comparative evaluation of such results from laboratory and field studies. The data obatined revealed conformity, completion and disagreement. Main difficulties result from the varying circumstances during spray application on to the high grown plants in the three systems even when using identical spray nossles. Missing boundaries to control and emasured losses by drift and evaporation in the field make direct comparison more difficult. The voltile fraction can be quantified only in the closed chamber during and after the application. In the case of lindane, 13% volatilized during spray application. Another 42% were lost from the plants and soil surfaces during the 28-day experimental period. The high volatile fraction explain the low recovery balance of only around 15% in outdoor lysimeters. The residue values of 0.3 mg/kg in potato foliage were the same in the field, outdoor lysimeters and closed chamber inspite of the fact that a lower lindane dose was received by the closed chamber system. However, the compact potato foliage obtained this dose directly from a short distance preventing contamination of the soil to a greater extend. Thus, the residue of lindane in the soil were lower to the factor of 10 in this case and in the potato tubers to a factor of 3.

column5: EFFECT OF STORAGE AND QUALITY OF WATER ON WETTABILITY AND SHELF-LIFE OF SOME PESTICIDE FORMULATIONS
column12: An experiment was conducted during 1986-87 to study the degradation of 7 pesticides after storing for 9 months at 4 different agro-climatic regions (tropic, tropic situated near sea-shore, mid-tropic and temperate) of Tamil Nadu and to study the effect of hard water on physical and chemical properties of pesticides. Temperate place (Uthagamandalam) proved favourable for the stability of liquid formulations than warm places, but adversely affected the stability of water-dispersible powder (WDP) formulation of mancozeb. Water with high pH and electrical conductivity (EC) affected the emulsion stability of endosulfan, dicofol, phosalone and fenvalerate and the wettability, but within the limits set by the Bureau of Indian Standards. The suspensibility of mancozeb was affected by storing at cool locations like Uthagamandalam beyond the limit, even immediately after procurement. The active ingredient content of the insecticides decreased marginally with the increase in acidity. Standard hard water of 0.53 EC appeared suitable for quality control to assess the physical properties, as the water having as high as 3.0 EC, equivalent to 1920 ppm hardness, is used for irrigation as well as for preparing the spray fluid.

column5: RESPONSE OF SUSCEPTIBLE AND TOLERANT PLANTS TO DICLOFOP-METHYL
column7: ZEITSCHRIFT FUR PFLANZENKRANKHEITEN UND PFLANZENSCHUTZ-JOURNAL OF PLANT DISEASES AND PROTECTION
column12: Diclofop-methyl (chemical name: 2-(4-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)-phenoxy)-methyl propanoate) is one of the modern selective foliar herbicides for the control of grass weeds. The studies of uptake, translocation and metabolism were conducted with 14C-diclofopmethyl with the tolerant species Triticum aestivum and Poa annua and the susceptible species Echinochloa crus-galli and Lolium multiflorum. Diclofop-methyl was taken up well by all investigated plant species. After foliar treatment, most of the remaining radioactive substance was confined to the treatment area. Only a small quantity was exported from the treated leaf and transported into other parts of the shoot. The translocation rate in the roots was extraordinarily low. After treatment of the roots, diclofopmethyl, when introduced via a nutrient solution, is transported to the shoots after a very short time. The amount of active ingredient taken up by leaves or roots, respectively, is not related to the sensitivity of plants to diclofop-methyl. Diclofop-methyl is metabolized very rapidly in the various plant species.
